newsitem.title: USA: Hydro Magnesium has no plan to hike US tag.
newsitem.headline: Hydro Magnesium has no plan to hike US tag.

text.p: Hydro Magnesium, part of Norway's Norsk Hydro A/S, said despite Friday's announcement of a hike in European pure magnesium prices, there were no plans to raise tags in North America.
Robert Edgar, Hydro Magnesium's vice president of marketing, said the company's European primary metal list price had lagged behind its North American prices and there was a need to narrow the gap.
Friday, Hydro raised its European producer price to 5.55 DM per kilogram from 5.40 DM a kilo. The alloy magnesium price was left unchanged at 5.40 DM a kilo.
Nevertheless, Hydro's European price is still below its North American price.
Officials at U.S. based Dow Magnesium were not immediately available to say if the company would be changing its European prices.
Asked if U.S prices would be hiked, Edgar replied: "It's always under review, but our first focus is on Europe. Until we can get Europe in line with North America, it does not make sense."
Edgar said the magnesium market had tightened up quite a bit, with a surprise fall in first quarter production in the West.
First quarter magnesium shipments were the best ever at 79,800 tonnes, the International Magnesium Association reported Wednesday.
Inventory at the end of the quarter was down 5,400 tonnes at 36,700 tonnes, and Western production fell 9,500 tonnes in the first quarter to 55,700 tonnes.
Edgar said Hydro was exporting some pure magnesium to the U.S. "It's not great amounts," Edgar said.
The company operates a production plant in Canada, and its bulk shipments to the U.S. is magnesium alloy for auto parts.
The U.S. countervailing duty on Canadian pure magnesium has been cut recently to 4.48 percent from 7.6 percent, with a recent review indicating a preliminary duty of 3.18 percent.
The final review's outcome is due by August, Edgar said.
There are no dumping duties on Canadian pure magnesium imports into the U.S.
